title: We've seen it with Swain; We've seen it with Kai'Sa
body:
Dear Riot,

From the gaming community, we humbly ask for you to release this new champion with the simple memory of the past two mistakes you have made with Kai'Sa and Swain. Despite how many people would love a broken champion upon release or morbid strength, we ask that next time you release a champion you do not buff them immediately or two patches after. 

We ask for a minimum of three weeks - almost a month worth of gameplay and data to see where players land. This large sample size with give enough statistical data on where you may want to change said champion and a large enough period for feedback.

With Kai'Sa being unstoppable every game and Swain being a monstrosity for a period of time before your demagation (word similar to deforestation where mages are gutted), I think there's enough evidence to support new champions do not deserve immediate buffs.

Thus, with your new champion, we hope you can wait and monitor its progress. Until then, let the hype live on.

Sincerely,
-

I don't understand the obsession with making new champions balanced on release. Getting a balanced champion in release is not a testament to the champions kit, nor is an unbalanced release proof that a champion is unbalanceable. If a champion is balanced on release, it's because Riot got lucky. That's it. There's pretty much no way to guarantee a champion is balanced on release, and certain champions (like mobile ones) are literally impossible to balance on release. 

Though i kind of have to agree with you here. Riot has a tendency of just going overboard with either buffs or nerfs on a champions release. Like how they gave Ornn massive straight buffs after his release, or buffed every aspect of Kai'sa's and Swain's kit, or how they thrashed all of Irelia's base stats a day after her release. Sometimes these champs just needs some QoL changes, like Swain's W range increase or Kai'sa's range increase but combining that with buffs to the rest of the kit is overkill.

And in the cases where they DON'T immediately make changes to a champ people still complain. Or is everyone going to ignore all the times that Riot has been patient with a champ's release only for everyone on the boards to say Riot is Satan for not nerfing or buffing them sooner?

I remember the week after Kai'Sa's release, where a great deal many players went to the Boards to warn Riot not to overbuff her, as they did with every previous release that started out with a low win rate. We brought up many past examples of champions suffering, including many who suffered much harder (e.g. Ivern, Tahm Kench, Gnar), before turning into complete balance monstrosities after a few misguided buffs, in addition to dominating the competitive scene the moment pro players figured them out. Riot's response to this was to reassure us that this time would be different, that these buffs were extensively researched and tested, and that they were sure to land Kai'Sa in just the right spot. They didn't. This total lack of hindsight worries me, because not only does it indicate that the devs balancing new champions aren't learning from past mistakes, but it also suggests that they _refuse_ to learn, and somehow believe that repeating the exact same methodology as before will somehow produce different results.

I absolutely agree with the OP here: one week, let alone a couple of days, is not a good enough window of time to properly assess a new champion's strength. There is always a learning curve, especially when Riot releases more complex or mechanically difficult champions, and it's only once a certain number of players have gone past that curve that we can have a better idea of where a champion lies in terms of power. What Riot is doing right now is that they're effectively balancing new releases around their win rate at under 15 games, which as anyone can check on any stat site, is always much lower than a champion's actual win rate over a larger spread. This effect is even more intense on new champions, because players are figuring their kit out on their own, and do not yet have any sort of solid build or guide to follow. Because of this, I think we need _at the very least_ one patch cycle to gauge a champion's power: if they're doing far too well, then for sure they could get hotfixed, and the same should likely be done if they have some crazy low win rate, e.g. some sub-40 win rate as was the case for Syndra and Azir (though both happened also because the champions were super buggy on release), but anything in-between should be met with patience and proper analysis.

I would've personally been okay with pure buffs to Kai'Sa, provided they were more moderate and informed by a more solid period of testing. As it stands, she received knee-jerk buffs after only too little time on Live, and it's this kind of rushed balancing method that continues to cause problems in League.
